intro: Harina nana, commonly known as the "dwarf snowbell," is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Himalayas. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers that bloom in spring. The plant typically grows to a height of less than 30 centimeters, with slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually white or pale blue, and it thrives in cool, moist environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Harina nana is considered a rare and endangered species.
